text: Welcome to my channel, The English Grammar Doctor. Have you ever wanted to speak English without stopping to translate in your head? You try to talk,
but your mind goes blank. Words don't come. You know the words, but they hide when you need them. You feel slow, shy,
or lost. That's because you're still thinking in your own language. But what if I told you you can think in English
naturally, even if you are a beginner?
And when you can think in English, you can speak it. This video will show you exactly how. I will guide you step by
step just like I learned. You don't need to be perfect. You just need to begin below. Do you have this problem too?
Comment yes below. Let's learn together now. Let's start.
Chapter 1.
The real reason you can't think in English yet. I know this feeling. You know many English words. You watch videos. You read books. You write
sometimes. But when it's time to speak, your mind becomes empty. You try to say something but the words do not come. You
feel slow. You feel blocked and you wonder why can't I think in English? I had the same problem. I studied English.
I knew grammar. I could write small essays in school. But still when someone asked me a question in English, I stayed
silent. I tried to understand their words. Then I tried to translate my answer. I thought in my language. Then I searched for English words. But by the
time I found the right word, the moment was gone. I felt stupid. I felt ashamed.
I thought maybe I was not smart enough.
Maybe English was too hard for me. But that was not true. The real problem was not me and it's not you. The real problem is habit. You have a strong
habit of thinking in your first language. This habit is not bad. It's normal. Your brain wants to feel safe.
So it uses the language it knows best.
That's why you think in your language first and then try to translate into English. But translation is slow. It is
not natural. It breaks your fluency. It steals your confidence. So if you want to speak English easily, you must build
a new habit. The habit of thinking in English. This is the truth no one told me. I thought I had to learn more grammar. I thought I needed 10,000 more
words. But no, I needed to train my brain to stay in English even with just a few words, even with short thoughts.
Let me take you back to one day. I was sitting in class. The teacher asked me a question in English. It was easy, just
one line. But I could not answer. My heart was beating fast. I looked down. I wanted to disappear. After class, I cried. I told myself, "You know the
answer, but you couldn't say it. Why?" That evening, I sat alone. I closed my eyes. I asked myself again, why can't I
speak? And then I realized, I never think in English. I only study English.
I only read English. I never live with it. I never talk to myself in English. I never make small thoughts in English.
That night, I decided to try something new. I looked at my table. I said, "This is a table." I looked at the wall. I
said that is a wall. I saw my hand. I said my hand is cold. It felt strange.
It felt funny. But I kept doing it.
Every day I said 10 small sentences only in my mind. No writing, no speaking, just thinking. And something changed.
After one week, my mind was faster. I could say easy things quickly. After a month, I was thinking in English before
I knew it. I saw a dog and thought, "It's cute." I felt hungry and thought, "I want food." These were not big thoughts, but they were mine in English.
That is the real way. You don't need perfect grammar. You don't need 10,000 words. You need small real thoughts in
English. This is how you start. This is how you become free. I will guide you step by step. You will learn how to think in English slowly, softly, with
love. It's not your memory. It's not your intelligence. It's your habit. And we are going to change that habit together.
Now, let's go to chapter 2. You will learn how to use your brain's secret power, pictures, instead of words, and
your thinking will become faster without translation.
Chapter 2. Think in pictures, not in words. When I was a child, I learned to speak my first language without a book.
I did not learn grammar rules. I did not study vocabulary lists. I saw things. I felt things. I wanted things. And slowly
I started saying words. I saw my mother and said mama. I saw a ball and said ball. My brain used pictures. And from
pictures came words, not the other way.
But when I started learning English, everything was different. I saw a word like apple. The teacher said apple means seb. So my brain made a connection
English word to native word to picture.
It was slow. It was extra work. And it made thinking in English very hard.
That's when I learned something powerful. Your brain doesn't need translation. It needs connection. It needs pictures. The brain is very smart,
but it's also very simple. It loves images. It remembers faces, colors, and shapes more than rules. So, if you want
to think in English faster, you must stop translating into your language. You must go straight from English to picture. Let me give you an example.
Look at your hand. Do you say hot first then hand? No, you just say hand. The picture is already there. Now look at
the door. Just say door. Don't think of the word in your language. Just look.
Just feel. Just say it in English. I use this trick every day. I picked five things in my room. A book, a pen, a
chair, a fan, a bottle. I looked at each one and I said the English word slowly, softly, like I was a baby again. book, pen, chair, fan, bottle. No
translation, only picture to English.
After one week, I added more. Red book, blue pen, big chair. I added feelings.
Cold fan, empty bottle. My brain started to love it. It felt light. It felt easy.
Because I stopped using my old language.
I was building a new road in my mind. A road of English. You can do this too.
Right now, look around you. Pick one object. Say it in English. Then close your eyes. See the object in your mind.
Say the word again. Do this again and again. Your brain will listen. Your brain will change. And when you hear someone say apple, your brain will see
an apple, not the word CB. This is freedom. This is fluency. This is the beginning of thinking in English.
Sometimes I used pictures on my phone. I downloaded apps with flashcards. They showed me photos with English words. No
translation, just image and English.
Tree, river, mountain, laugh, cry. It helped me think faster. I stopped needing to remember two languages. I started living in one. And one day I was
walking outside. I saw a flower. I didn't think of the word in my first language. I just smiled and thought, "Beautiful flower." That moment made me
proud. It was small, but to me it was big. It meant my brain had changed. It meant English was becoming natural. You
don't need to be perfect. You don't need to remember every word. Just practice this every day. Look, feel, say, picture
to English. No translation, no stress.
You are building a new home inside your mind. A home where English lives. A home where thoughts are light, simple, and
true. Now, in the next chapter, I will show you how to start thinking in English with tiny sentences. This step will help you move from just words to
real thoughts. Thoughts that stay in your brain. Thoughts that become speech.
Let's keep going. You are doing great.
Chapter 3. Start thinking in English with tiny sentences.
After I learned to think in pictures, something was still missing. I could say words like pen, book, table. But I couldn't think in full ideas. My
thoughts were broken. I wanted to say more, but I didn't know how. That's when I realized I needed to make tiny English
sentences. Not long, not hard, just small, simple, honest sentences from my mind. I remember my first one. It was
this. I am tired. It was a normal day. I came home from school. My body was heavy. I wanted to sleep. And suddenly,
instead of saying it in my language, I whispered, "I am tired." I felt something new. It was not just a sentence. It was my feeling in English.
After that, I tried more. It is hot. I am hungry. This is my book. These were baby sentences, but to me, they were
magic because they were real thoughts in English. Not grammar rules, not test answers, just me thinking in a new way.
So, I made a small plan. Every day I told myself I would think five tiny English sentences. That's all. Just five. I didn't write them. I didn't say
them out loud. I just thought them while walking, while eating, while brushing my teeth. Here are some of my early ones. I
see a bird. My hands are cold. She is talking. The sky is blue. I want water.
These were small, but they were true.
They helped me feel closer to English.
Like English was not outside me, it was inside me. And when I made mistakes, I didn't stop. Sometimes I said, "He are
walking." Then I caught it and changed.
He is walking. That little correction helped me remember. My brain was learning by itself, not by a book, not by a test, but by thinking real life in
English. You can do this too right now.
Look around. Say something in your mind.
This is my phone. I like tea. My shoes are black. These thoughts are seeds. If you plant them every day, they will
grow. And soon your English will grow, too. Sometimes I even made a game. I would walk around my room and describe
everything I saw. This is a chair. The chair is brown. The brown chair is soft.
I kept building the sentence little by little from three words to four, from four to five. It was fun. It was real.
These tiny sentences gave me power. I didn't need big grammar. I didn't need difficult words. I just needed truth in
simple form. And that's what fluency is.
Not speaking fast, not sounding perfect, but saying what you feel, what you see, what you want to yourself in English.
Some days I felt lazy. Some days my brain didn't want to in English. That's okay. I still tried one sentence, just one. Even that helped. One is better
than zero. I told this to myself often and I want you to remember it too. Maybe today your sentence is I don't know much
English. That's okay. Tomorrow it will be I am learning English. One day it will be I can speak English now. All
because you started with tiny thoughts.
Now in the next chapter I will share my favorite method of all. How I talk to myself in my brain like I was speaking
to a real person. It's a secret that helped me when I had no one to practice English with. You don't want to miss it.
Let's move forward together. You are doing better than you think. Chapter 4.
Talk in your brain like it's a real person. I was alone in my room. I had no one to practice English with. My friends
were busy. My parents didn't speak English. I felt stuck. I had all these words in my head, but no one to talk to.
I wanted to speak, but who would listen?
That's when I discovered something that changed my life. I started talking to myself in English, not out loud, not for
anyone else, just in my brain, like a little conversation was happening inside me. At first, it felt strange. I asked
myself a question. Then I answered.
It was quiet. It was simple, but it worked. I would say things like, "How are you?" "I'm fine." "Just tired." What
did you eat? I ate rice and chicken. Did you like it? Yes, it was very good.
These were not perfect sentences, but they were mine and they were in English.
It became a habit. When I was walking, I asked myself, "Where am I going?" I answered, "To the shop." Then I asked,
"What will I buy?" And I said, "Some bread and milk." This simple brain talk made English feel close to me. I wasn't
waiting for someone else. I was my own practice partner. My mind became my classroom. My thoughts became my teacher. You can do this too. You don't
need books. You don't need internet.
You just need one thing, your mind.
Start asking yourself easy questions.
Answer with easy words. Don't worry about grammar. Don't try to be fast.
Just talk to yourself like a friend. If you don't know what to say, try this.
Ask, "What time is it?" Answer, "It's 8:00." Ask, "What's the weather?" Answer, "It's hot and sunny." Ask, "How
do I feel?" Answer, "I feel happy." Now, you are not just thinking in English.
You are talking in English inside your brain. That's powerful. That's how fluency starts. Sometimes I even use this brain talk to tell stories. I would
imagine I was talking to someone about my day. Today I went to the market. I saw a dog. It was barking. I bought
bananas. They were yellow and sweet. My brain was telling little stories in English. I was building my fluency without a partner. One day I was on a
bus. I looked outside and said in my mind, "There is a man walking. He has a red shirt. He looks tired." No one heard
me, but I smiled because I was speaking English in my brain without fear. This kind of practice helped me in real
conversations because when someone spoke to me, my brain was ready. I had already practiced many small answers. I had
already played with simple questions.
So, I didn't freeze. I could respond slowly but clearly. You don't need to be shy when you talk to yourself. No one
will laugh. No one will correct you. You are safe. You are learning. You are growing. This is your private practice.
and it works. So tonight when you are brushing your teeth, try it. Ask yourself, did I do well today?
Answer, yes, I learned English. I practiced. That one small conversation is the beginning of fluency.
Now, in the next chapter, I'll show you how I slowly started to replace my native words with English words step by step. This helped my brain stay in
English longer. It made me feel like English was part of my real life. Let's keep walking this path together. One thought at a time. Chapter 5. Replace
your native words with English words.
Slowly. I remember one day I was in the kitchen. My mom asked me to pass the salt. In my mind, I said the word in my
language. Then I thought, wait, what's salt in English?
It took me a few seconds. Then I said, "Salt." That was the moment I realized something important. I was still thinking in my
native language first, then trying to find the English word. This was slowing me down. It was making my brain work too
hard. I had to stop the translation.
But how? Not by force. Not at all at once. I didn't try to change my brain in one day. That would be too hard. I started slowly, one word at a time. I
picked easy words I used every day, like book, water, pen, bag. Every time I saw them, I said the word in English in my
mind. I replaced the word in my language with the English word. When I saw water, I didn't think pawnie. I trained my
brain to just say water. When I looked at the door, I said door, not darwaza, just door. It felt strange at first. My
brain wanted to go back to my old words, but I was gentle. I didn't fight. I just repeated again and again. And slowly,
the English words became normal. They became mine. Afterwards, I moved to small actions. I started using English for things I do every day, like I open
the door. I eat rice. I wear my shoes. I wash my hands. Every time I did these things, I said them in English.
Sometimes out loud, sometimes in my mind. I didn't care if anyone heard.
This was my training. Then came feelings. Feelings are deep. They stay in the heart. But I wanted to feel them in English, too. So, I started small. I
am tired. I am happy. I feel cold.
I miss my friend.
These thoughts became part of me and I stopped needing my old language for them. They lived in English now. Some
days my brain forgot. It used my native words again. That's okay. I smiled and corrected myself. No, not that word. Use
the English one. No anger, no pressure, just a quiet reminder like teaching a child with love. You can do this too.
Start today. Choose five simple things around you. Say them in English every time you see them. Don't worry if you
forget. Just try again. Over time, your brain will build a new habit, a new system, a new way of thinking. Here's a
trick I used. I made little paper tags and wrote English words on them. I put them on objects in my room. On the wall,
I wrote wall. On the mirror, I wrote mirror. On the clock, I wrote clock.
Every time I looked, I saw the English word. And slowly, I stopped needing the translation.
Fluency is not about speaking fast. It's about thinking directly in English. That starts with small replacements. One word, then one sentence, then one
feeling. And one day you'll realize your brain didn't use your first language at all. You'll say a full sentence in
English and you won't even remember the old words. That's when you know your mind is changing. You are becoming fluent.
In the next chapter, I'll share how I used my daily life to think more and more in English. You'll see how every moment, brushing, walking, eating, can
help you grow. Let's keep going step by step, word by word.
Chapter 6. How I used my daily life to think in English.
One morning I was brushing my teeth. I looked in the mirror and a thought came to me in English. I am brushing my
teeth. It was a simple sentence, but I smiled because that thought used to come in my own language. That day it came in
English. That moment gave me hope. It showed me that even small daily actions could help me learn. After that, I made
a decision. I would use my daily life to think in English. Not just study time, not just class time. Every moment of the
day could be a chance to think. When I woke up, I said in my mind, I am waking up now. When I looked out the window, I
said, the sky is blue. When I drank tea, I said, "I like this tea. It is warm." These were my real thoughts, real feelings, not grammar practice, not
vocabulary lists, just me living in English. It started to become a game.
When I walked to school, I would describe what I saw. A red car, a boy with a bag, a tree with no leaves. These were small observations, but they made
my brain active. English became part of my walk. When I stood in line, I used that waiting time. I looked around and made sentences in my head. She is
talking on the phone. That child is crying. I think he is tired. Sometimes I guessed what people were thinking. He looks worried. Maybe she is going to
work. It was fun and it trained my thinking. When I cooked with my mom, I said the steps in English. I cut the onions. I put oil in the pan. Now I stir
the rice. The smells and the actions helped the words stick in my brain. I didn't even need to memorize them. I was
living them. At night, I did the same. I am lying down now. I feel sleepy. Today was a long day. These were my bedtime
thoughts in English. Slowly, my brain started to prefer English for small things. I didn't push it. I didn't force
it. I just opened the door. An English walked in. You can do this, too. Don't wait for the perfect moment. Use your
real life, your toothbrush, your food, your shoes, your steps, your feelings.
They are all English practice. Here's something I did that helped a lot. I set one hour each day as English time.
During that hour, I told myself no thinking in my language, only English.
If I made mistakes, it was okay. If I forgot a word, I skipped it. I just tried to stay inside English, even for small thoughts. At first, it was hard.
My brain wanted to run back to my old language, but I kept trying. And every day it got a little easier. You don't
need books for this. You don't need a teacher. Your daily life is your teacher. Your actions are your lessons.
Your thoughts are your homework. Even if you're doing something boring, washing dishes, folding clothes, walking alone.
Use it. Think in English. Say something small. This plate is dirty. I fold the shirt. I am walking fast. These tiny moments are powerful. One day I was
helping my younger brother tie his shoes. He asked me something in our language and without thinking I replied in English. Wait, let me help you. He
looked surprised. I was surprised too.
But it made me proud. My mind was now thinking English first. This is how fluency grows. Not in books, not in tests, but in life, in dishes, in
traffic, in laughter, in quiet. Every moment is a seed. Plant it in English.
Watch it grow. In the next chapter, I will tell you about one method that changed everything. Shadowing. It's how
I copied native speakers and trained my brain to think and speak fast. You will love it. So, let's keep going. You are
doing something amazing. Chapter 7. The secret power of shadowing to train the brain. I remember the first time I heard
the word shadowing. I didn't understand what it meant. I thought, is it about shadows?
But then I learned the truth and it changed my life. Shadowing is when you listen to a native speaker and then copy
them out loud right away like an echo, like a shadow. At first, it felt strange. I played a short video. The speaker said, "Hi, how are you?" I
paused, then I said, "Hi, how are you?" I tried to match their voice, their speed, even their emotion. It was hard, but it felt exciting. It felt real
that day. I found something powerful.
Shadowing was not just repeating words.
It was training my brain to think in English. It helped me stop translating.
It helped me speak faster. It helped me feel the rhythm of real English. I started small, just 5 minutes a day. I played a short video with slow, clear
voices. I watched one line. I paused. I repeated. Automatic. You stopped thinking in your language. You just speak. I remember one morning I shadowed
a short story. The speaker said, "It was a sunny day." I said, "It was a sunny day." Then they said, "The birds were singing." I said, "The birds were
singing." My mouth felt slow at first, but with each sentence, I got faster and I smiled because I was speaking real English. Later that day, I walked
outside. I saw the sun and in my mind, the sentence came, "It's a sunny day." It came without thinking. That's the
power of shadowing. It plants English in your brain deeply. Sometimes I walked around my room and shadowed. I listened
to a podcast and I repeated the words.
My voice followed their voice. My thoughts followed their thoughts. I didn't stop to understand every word. I didn't worry about grammar. I just
copied like a child learning to speak.
And guess what? One day, I didn't need the video. The words came by themselves.
My brain remembered the phrases. My mouth knew the rhythm. I was thinking in English without trying. You can do this
too. Start with a short clip, maybe 1 minute. Choose something easy. Maybe a cartoon. Maybe a story. Maybe a daily
conversation. Listen, pause, repeat. Do it again. Feel the sound. Feel the sentence. Be the shadow. If you do this every day, even for 5 minutes, your
fluency will grow. You will sound more natural. You will think faster. You will stop translating.
Shadowing helped me feel like English was inside me. Not just a subject, not just a skill, but part of my voice, part
of my life. Here's a tip. Don't only shadow words, shadow feelings. If the speaker is happy, you smile and speak
with joy. If they are serious, you speak calmly. Match their tone. match their music. English is not only words, it's
also emotion. Now, in the next chapter, I will tell you how I use listening to train my brain even more. I'll show you
how not all listening is equal and how I used focused emotional listening to change the way I think. Let's keep going. Your voice is growing. Your
English is coming alive.
Chapter 8. listening that trains your brain to think in English. For a long time, I thought listening was easy. I
played English songs. I watched movies.
I heard words. But still, I couldn't speak. I couldn't think in English. I asked myself, why is my listening not working? Then I understood something
important. Not all listening helps. Some listening goes in your ears and disappears. But some listening stays in your brain. It trains your thoughts.
That is the kind of listening I needed.
The first step was to listen with purpose. Before I listened just for fun, but now I listen to learn. I chose content that was slow, clear, and close
to my level. I didn't try to understand everything. I just focused on how words were used. I listened again and again.
One day I listened to a simple English podcast. The speaker said, "Today I will go to the store." I paused. I repeated it in my mind. Then
I played it again.
This time I noticed the rhythm. Today I will go to the store. I copied the sound in my brain and slowly that sentence
became mine. That night when I thought about my plans, the sentence came, "Tomorrow I will go to school." It came
naturally, not because I memorized it, but because I heard it many times. It entered my thoughts. This is the power
of good listening. You don't just hear English, you feel it. You don't just understand, you remember. And most of all, you start to think in English. I
made a habit. Every morning, I listened to one short English clip. I closed my eyes. I didn't read subtitles. I focused
only on the voice. I tried to guess the meaning. I imagined the situation. I pictured the words. This kind of deep listening helped me think faster.
In the evening, I played the same clip again. This time I spoke with it. I whispered the words with the speaker. I am going to cook dinner. I said it
softly. I like to walk in the park. I said it with feeling. It was like music.
My brain loved it. I learned a big secret. Repeating the same listening again and again is more powerful than always listening to something new. One
clip five times is better than five clips one time. Repetition makes the sentence stay. And when it stays, you can think it, you can say it. Another
secret, listen to what you love. If you love stories, listen to stories. If you love travel, find travel videos. If you
like cooking, find recipes in English.
Listening becomes stronger when your heart is interested because then your brain listens more deeply. Sometimes I didn't understand every word. That's
okay. I focused on what I did understand. I felt the meaning. I followed the voice and slowly my understanding grew. One day I was
walking and a phrase came into my mind.
It's a beautiful day. I didn't plan it.
I didn't study it. I had just heard it many times in songs, in shows, in videos. It lived inside me. Now, that's
when I knew my listening was changing my brain. You can do this, too. Choose one voice, one video, one story. Listen
every day, not with stress, but with love, with interest, with joy. Close your eyes, feel the rhythm, feel the words. Let them enter your thoughts. Now
in the next chapter I will tell you how I stopped being afraid of speaking mistakes. This fear used to stop me from
thinking in English. But once I beat that fear everything changed. Let's keep going. Your ears are ready. Your thoughts are stronger. English is
becoming your voice. Chapter nine. How I stopped being afraid of speaking mistakes.
In the beginning, I was always scared to speak, not because I didn't know the words, but because I was afraid of
saying something wrong. I thought, what if they laugh at me? What if I make a mistake?
So, I stayed quiet. I kept the words inside my head. Even when I wanted to speak, my mouth stayed shut. I listened.
I nodded. I smiled. But inside, I was screaming. I wanted to talk. I wanted to be part of the group. But fear stopped
me. Then one day something small changed my life. I was in class. The teacher asked a question. I knew the answer. I
wanted to raise my hand. But again, fear came. My heart beat fast. My hands felt cold. But I didn't want to live like
this anymore. So I said the sentence. I made a mistake, a small one. I said, "He go to school instead of he goes to
school." The class was quiet. Then the teacher smiled and said gently, almost correct, "Try again." I tried again. He
goes to school. She nodded, "Good." And that was it. No one laughed, no one pointed, nothing bad happened. But inside me, something amazing happened.
The fear got smaller. I felt proud. I had spoken even with a mistake and that gave me power. After that I allowed myself to speak more. I made many
mistakes. I said the wrong tense. I forgot words. I used the wrong word. But I also learned. I listened to myself. I
corrected myself. And the more I spoke, the more my fear disappeared. I realized something big.
Mistakes are not the enemy. Fear is the enemy. And the only way to fight fear is to take small steps. I made a rule for
myself. I said one mistake a day keeps the fear away. Every day I tried to say one sentence out loud. If I made a mistake, I smiled and corrected it. I
treated it like a game, like a baby learning to walk. When a baby falls, no one laughs. They cheer. So I started to
cheer for myself. I told myself, "Good job. You tried. You spoke. That's success." And slowly my mind changed. I stopped thinking. What if I say it
wrong? Instead, I started thinking, "Let me try. Let me speak. Let me learn." You can do this, too. Don't hide from
mistakes. Welcome them. Learn from them.
They are your teachers. They show you where to grow. The more mistakes you make, the faster you learn. Speak to yourself. Speak to a friend. Speak to
your phone. Speak in the mirror. It doesn't matter. What matters is this.
You speak even if it's not perfect, especially when it's not perfect because perfection comes later. But courage must
come now. In the next chapter, I will show you how I learned to think faster with fewer words. You don't need to say
long sentences to be fluent. You just need to think clearly and speak simply.
That's how real fluency begins. Keep going. You're doing so well.
Chapter 10. How to think faster with fewer words.
When I first started thinking in English, I thought I needed big words. I thought long sentences would make me sound smart. But that idea made
everything harder. I waited too long to speak. I searched for difficult vocabulary. I tried to remember grammar rules. And in that waiting, I lost my
chance. The moment to speak would pass and I stayed silent again. It made me feel slow and sad. But slowly I began to understand the truth.
Fluency is not about saying more. It's about saying what you need clearly and simply.
One day I was talking to a new friend.
She was also learning English, but she spoke fast, not with big words, but with simple ones. She said things like, "I
like this. Let's go. It's okay." I was surprised. She didn't know many words, but she sounded confident. Her voice was
soft. Her sentence is short, but I could feel her meaning.
That day, I realized something important. You don't need big words to think fast. You need small words used often.
I started to train my mind. I stopped trying to make perfect sentences.
Instead, I made short ones. I said what I felt in three or four words. I don't know. This is good. I need help. These
were not special words, but they were powerful. They helped me speak without fear. They helped me think fast and speak fast. The more I did this, the
more natural it felt. I stopped waiting.
I started talking. At night, I made a list of simple sentences. I read them again and again. What's this? Are you okay? That's fine. Thank you so much.
These were my tools. These were my weapons against fear. I didn't need to memorize a hundred rules. I just needed
to build my own English voice with few words said with meaning. I also began to watch how native speakers talked. I
noticed something strange. They didn't always speak in full grammar. They used short forms. They said, "Got to go. Want
to eat?" I don't know. It wasn't textbook English, but it was real. It was fast and it worked. I started to copy that style. I allowed myself to be
natural. I let go of the fear of sounding wrong. I focused on being clear. One time I met a tourist who needed help. She asked me which way to
the station.
